required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Understanding How Anaesthesia Affects ECT Outcomes
clinical_study.official_title: Understanding How Anaesthesia Affects ECT Outcomes

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of New South Wales

clinical_study.source: The University of New South Wales

brief_summary.textblock: This study will examine how anaesthetic technique affects ECT outcomes. Specifically, the investigators will examine how: 1) the time interval between anaesthetic and ECT stimulus, and 2) the ventilation rate before ECT stimulus, impacts on the quality of the EEG (this is a recording of brain activity during ECT and is used to judge the quality of a seizure and to guide individual patient dosing).

detailed_description.textblock: This study aims to examine how the time interval between administration of anaesthetic agent and ECT stimulus delivery impacts upon measures of EEG quality (seizure quality).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Each participant will receive all four treatment conditions in randomly allocated sequence during their ECT course. That is, participants will receive either short or long anaesthetic-ECT stimulus time interval treatments, and normal or hyperventilation treatments - this results in four possible combinations, which individual participants will cycle through in random order during their ECT course (e.g. short-hyperventilation, long-normal ventilation, short-normal ventilation, long-hyperventilation).
study_design_info.masking_description: Both participants and the outcome assessor (analysing EEGs) will be blinded.

primary_outcome.measure: EEG Seizure Quality Rating using the EEG Seizure Quality Rating Sheet utilised by MacPherson et al
primary_outcome.time_frame: Outcome measures will be collected immediately after each ECT treatment from the first treatment until the end of the ECT course, an estimated total of four to six weeks for most participants
primary_outcome.description: EEG quality will be rated manually for each ECT treatment undertaken by a participant until the conclusion of their ECT course. This rating will be done using the EEG Seizure Quality Rating Sheet utilised by MacPherson et al - low dose lignocaine added to propofol does not attenuate the response to electroconvulsive therapy; Journal of Affective Disorders, 2010; 126: 330-333

intervention.description: The intervention in this study is the time interval between anaesthetic administration and ECT stimulus

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients treated with a course of ECT
Exclusion Criteria:
- Use of non-standard anaesthetic agents in ECT (e.g. ketamine)

overall_official.affiliation: The University of New South Wales

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: The University of New South Wales
